message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is most likely experiencing acute hypocalcemia due to parathyroid removal during the surgery. The hand sign is called "trousseau sign" and is indicative of hypocalcemia. The best initial treatment would be intravenous calcium gluconate to quickly raise serum calcium levels. Oral calcium and calcitriol may take too long to have an effect, while human recombinant parathyroid hormone is not indicated in acute hypocalcemia. Oral magnesium is also not indicated in this situation.

The hand turning and difficulty breathing suggest severe hypocalcemia. The best initial treatment is intravenous calcium gluconate to rapidly increase serum calcium levels. Oral calcium and calcitriol, along with other measures, can be used for long-term treatment of hypocalcemia post-thyroidectomy.
